elements.content: New Ln-metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs), {[Ln­(2,7-NDS)­(IP)­(OH)­(H2O)2]·mH2O} n [Ln = Sm 1, Eu 2, Gd 3, Tb 4, Dy 5, m = 0.5–0; 2,7-NDS = 2,7-naphthalenedisulfonate, and IP = 1H-imidazo­[4,5-f]­[1,10]-phenanthroline) were obtained by the hydrothermal method. The Ln-MOFs feature one-dimensional double chain structures. The photoluminescent properties of these complexes were investigated. Notably, the Eu-MOF exhibits a broad excitation band from 250 to 400 nm in the UV–vis region, and it presents red emission from the 5D0 → 7F J transitions (where J = 0–4) of the Eu3+ ion. It is noteworthy that it still shows intense emission under near-visible irradiation at 350 nm < λex < 385 nm. Using the Eu-MOF as a luminescent sensor, the detection of Fe3+/Ag+ and ornidazole (ODZ)/ronidazole (RDZ) in aqueous medium was realized with long excitation wavelengths of 368 nm or even 385 nm in the near-visible region. This work provides a new approach to designing an efficient red emission with broad-band and near-visible light excitation and with luminescent chemosensor capability for biological applications. In addition, the Eu-MOF red light incorporated Gd-MOF blue-green light, and a white-light emission is realized based on a two-component Gd0.99803Eu0.00197 doped complex. Magnetic studies of the Dy-MOF reveal that it has a single-molecule magnet and slow magnetic relaxation behavior with an energy barrier U eff of 82.39 K.

elements.content: One-dimensional Ln-metal−organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) were constructed from 2,7-naphthalenedisulfonate and 1H-imidazo­[4,5-f]­[1,10]-phenanthroline ligands. The Eu-MOF exhibits a large broad excitation band and intensity red emission, even when excited with near-visible irradiation, which can be used as a luminescent sensor. The Dy-MOF reveals a single-molecule magnet.

The Eu-MOF exhibits a large broad excitation band and intensity red emission, even when excited with near-visible irradiation, which can be used as a luminescent sensor. The Dy-MOF reveals a single-molecule magnet.

elements.content: Lanthanide (Ln) elements have characteristic fluorescence and magnetism due to their 4f n electrons, which make metal–organic frameworks based on the Ln center (Ln-MOFs) new multifunctional materials, with broad potential applications in the fields of luminescence, magnetism, gas storage, and catalysis. Ln3+ luminescence features intense narrow-band emission and long emission lifetimes. The absorption coefficients of Ln3+ f–f transitions are very low, which result in ineffective luminescence due to their forbidden electronic transitions under the electric dipole selection rules. However, Ln3+ complexes with organic ligands can emit strong fluorescence. The organic ligands, especially conjugated organic compounds, absorb in the UV and visible regions, producing an antenna effect, by which energy is transferred to the Ln3+ ions, leading to f–f emissions of Ln3+ ions and thus to luminescence of Ln3+. The excitation wavelengths of luminescent Ln3+ complexes are generally in the UV range 200–350 nm and appear to be limited to <400 nm. A challenge in the chemistry of the lanthanide ions is to develop luminescent Eu3+- complexes that can be sensitized by visible light. Such complexes are particularly important for biomedical and technological applications because visible light is less harmful to organisms due to its lower energy. There is one traditional approach to achieving visible-light excitation. The strategy is to synthesize the Eu3+-complex by the π-conjugated organic molecule as the ligand that makes the excitation wavelength in the visible region and to achieve visible-light excitation for the Eu3+ complex. So, Ln-based luminescence provides a good platform for biological and environmental applications. The lanthanide ions most commonly used in luminescence and luminescence sensing applications are Eu3+ or Tb3+ because of their strong red or green luminescence, by the naked eye in UV light, respectively. Ln-complexes as sensors for the detection of cations, anions, and molecules have been designed. In addition, the Ln3+ ion has large unquenched orbital angular momentum that displays unique magnetic properties. The large ground-state spin and the magnetic anisotropy of the Ln3+ ion create an interesting single-molecule magnet (SMM) . SMMs have attracted great interest because of their potential applications in molecular spintronics, high-density information storage, and quantum computing. The Dy3+ ion because of its spin–orbit coupling, magnetic anisotropy, and a crystal field effect is a candidate for SMMs, which exhibits slow magnetic relaxation behavior with a high effective energy barrier (U eff) and high blocking temperature. These factors have led to increasing efforts to construct novel Ln-MOFs as potential multifunctional materials, such as materials with intriguing luminescence and magnetic properties. Thus, Ln3+ ions are connected by ligands, construing Ln-MOFs as fluorescent sensors and SMMs materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Lanthanide (Ln) elements have characteristic fluorescence and magnetism due to their 4f n  electrons, which make metal-organic frameworks based on the Ln center (Ln-MOFs) new multifunctional materials, with broad potential applications in the fields of luminescence, magnetism, gas storage, and catalysis. Ln3+ luminescence features intense narrow-band emission and long emission lifetimes. The absorption coefficients of Ln3+ f-f transitions are very low, which result in ineffective luminescence due to their forbidden electronic transitions under the electric dipole selection rules. However, Ln3+ complexes with organic ligands can emit strong fluorescence. The organic ligands, especially conjugated organic compounds, absorb in the UV and visible regions, producing an antenna effect, by which energy is transferred to the Ln3+ ions, leading to f-f emissions of Ln3+ ions and thus to luminescence of Ln3+. The excitation wavelengths of luminescent Ln3+ complexes are generally in the UV range 200-350 nm and appear to be limited to <400 nm. A challenge in the chemistry of the lanthanide ions is to develop luminescent Eu3+- complexes that can be sensitized by visible light. Such complexes are particularly important for biomedical and technological applications because visible light is less harmful to organisms due to its lower energy. There is one traditional approach to achieving visible-light excitation. The strategy is to synthesize the Eu3+-complex by the π-conjugated organic molecule as the ligand that makes the excitation wavelength in the visible region and to achieve visible-light excitation for the Eu3+ complex. So, Ln-based luminescence provides a good platform for biological and environmental applications. The lanthanide ions most commonly used in luminescence and luminescence sensing applications are Eu3+ or Tb3+ because of their strong red or green luminescence, by the naked eye in UV light, respectively. Ln-complexes as sensors for the detection of cations, anions, and molecules have been designed. In addition, the Ln3+ ion has large unquenched orbital angular momentum that displays unique magnetic properties. The large ground-state spin and the magnetic anisotropy of the Ln3+ ion create an interesting single-molecule magnet (SMM) . SMMs have attracted great interest because of their potential applications in molecular spintronics, high-density information storage, and quantum computing. The Dy3+ ion because of its spin-orbit coupling, magnetic anisotropy, and a crystal field effect is a candidate for SMMs, which exhibits slow magnetic relaxation behavior with a high effective energy barrier (U eff) and high blocking temperature. These factors have led to increasing efforts to construct novel Ln-MOFs as potential multifunctional materials, such as materials with intriguing luminescence and magnetic properties. Thus, Ln3+ ions are connected by ligands, construing Ln-MOFs as fluorescent sensors and SMMs materials.

elements.content: In this work, new LnOFs, {[Ln­(2,7-NDS)­(IP)­OH)­(H2O)2]­·mH2O} n [Ln = Sm 1, Eu 2, Gd 3, Tb 4, Dy 5, m = 0.5–0; 2,7-NDS = 2,7-naphthalenedisulfonate, and IP = 1H-imidazo­[4,5-f]­[1,10]-phenanthroline) were constructed. A rigid 2,7-NDS ligand incorporating a rigid IP ligand links Ln3+ ions to form 1-D double chain architectures. The IP ligand contains the two donor N atoms as chelate coordination sites and free Lewis basic N atoms sites on the IP ligand, which shows the potential for the sensing metal ions. In addition, we note that the compound IP exhibits a broad absorption band with maxima at approximately 368, 392, and 415 nm, which reside at longer wavelengths. So it is possible to achieve the Eu3+/Tb3+ luminescence under near-UV to visible light (350–400 nm). Thus, it is beneficial for the construction of MOFs with high chemical and thermal stability as well as with designated chemical or physical functionalities. The resulting MOFs provide an excellent opportunity to study fluorescence, fluorescence sensing, and magnetic properties. The Eu-MOF exhibits particularly interesting red luminescence that can be excited over a broad absorption window toward the visible region, which provides important information for the future application of the material. The complex shows highly efficient luminescent sensing for Fe3+/Ag+ ions and ornidazole (ODZ)/ronidazole (RDZ) in aqueous medium at wavelengths of 368 or 385 nm near-visible light. Furthermore, the magnetic properties of Dy-MOF (5) were investigated, and it exhibits SMM and slow magnetic relaxation behavior.

A rigid 2,7-NDS ligand incorporating a rigid IP ligand links Ln3+ ions to form 1-D double chain architectures. The IP ligand contains the two donor N atoms as chelate coordination sites and free Lewis basic N atoms sites on the IP ligand, which shows the potential for the sensing metal ions. In addition, we note that the compound IP exhibits a broad absorption band with maxima at approximately 368, 392, and 415 nm, which reside at longer wavelengths. So it is possible to achieve the Eu3+/Tb3+ luminescence under near-UV to visible light (350-400 nm). Thus, it is beneficial for the construction of MOFs with high chemical and thermal stability as well as with designated chemical or physical functionalities. The resulting MOFs provide an excellent opportunity to study fluorescence, fluorescence sensing, and magnetic properties. The Eu-MOF exhibits particularly interesting red luminescence that can be excited over a broad absorption window toward the visible region, which provides important information for the future application of the material. Furthermore, the magnetic properties of Dy-MOF (5) were investigated, and it exhibits SMM and slow magnetic relaxation behavior.

elements.content: All reagents were commercially purchased and used without further purification. Infrared (IR) spectra using KBr pellets were produced using a Bruker Tensor37 spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were measured by a Vario EL elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was carried out on a PANalytical X’pert PRO MPD diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy was obtained from an Agilent ICP-OES730. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on an HCT-2 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C in air atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. The UV–vis spectra were recorded using an U-3900H spectrophotometer (Japan Hitachi company). The fluorescence spectra were produced on an FL7000 spectrophotometer. The lifetimes and quantum yield were measured on an FLS920 steady state and time-resolved fluorescence spectrometer (Edinburgh Instrument). The magnetic measurements of Dy-MOF were investigated on SQUIDMPMS3 magnetometers.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents were commercially purchased and used without further purification. Infrared (IR) spectra using KBr pellets were produced using a Bruker Tensor37 spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were measured by a Vario EL elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was carried out on a PANalytical X'pert PRO MPD diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy was obtained from an Agilent ICP-OES730. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on an HCT-2 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C in air atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The UV-vis spectra were recorded using an U-3900H spectrophotometer (Japan Hitachi company). The fluorescence spectra were produced on an FL7000 spectrophotometer. The lifetimes and quantum yield were measured on an FLS920 steady state and time-resolved fluorescence spectrometer (Edinburgh Instrument). The magnetic measurements of Dy-MOF were investigated on SQUIDMPMS3 magnetometers.

elements.content: A 25 mL Teflon cup with a mixture of Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1 mmol), 2,7-NDS (0.15 mmol), and IP (0.1 mmol), NaOH (0.1 mL, 1 mol/L), and water (10 mL) was heated at 180 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless crystals were obtained. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C23H19SmN4O9S2O­·0.5H2O (1): C, 38.43; N, 7.79; H, 2.78%. Found (%): C, 38.99; N, 7.71; H, 2.77%. The X-ray single crystal data of complexes 1–5 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied using the program SADABS. The crystal structures were obtained by direct method and refined by a full matrix least-squares method on F2 using SHELXS 97 and SHELXL 97 programs. All hydrogen atoms were fixed geometrically by a mixture of independent and constrained refinement. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths/angles are provided in and Table S1, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

The X-ray single crystal data of complexes 1-5 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied using the program SADABS. The crystal structures were obtained by direct method and refined by a full matrix least-squares method on F2 using SHELXS 97 and SHELXL 97 programs. All hydrogen atoms were fixed geometrically by a mixture of independent and constrained refinement. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths/angles are provided in  and Table S1, respectively.

The synthetic Ln-MOFs (1–5) crystallize in the triclinic system, P1̅ space group (). Complexes 1–5 are isostructural 1-D double chain structures. A comparison of the crystal data (Table S1) for 1–5 shows that the corresponding Ln–O, Ln–N, and Ln···Ln distances decrease in the order of complexes 1–5, which is consistent with the radius Sm3+ > Eu3+ > Gd3+ > Tb3+ > Dy3+. Eu-MOF, 2, is used as an example to discuss the crystal structure. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one Eu3+ ion, one 2,7-NDS ligand, one IP ligand, one OH group, and two water molecules (a). The eight-coordinate Eu3+ ion is completed by two O atoms of 2,7-NDS ligands, two N atoms of chelating IP ligand, two OH groups, and two water molecules, forming a [EuO6N2] distorted square antiprism unit. The bond distances of Eu–O (SO3 group), Eu–O (water), and Eu–N are in the range from 2.474(4) to 2.452(4) Å, 2.274(4) to 2.492(4) Å and 2.563(4) to 2.628(4) Å with an average of 2.463, 2.377, and 2.596 Å, respectively. The one SO3 group of the 2,7-NDS ligand adopts a μ2:η1η1η0 bridging coordination mode and is bonded to two Eu3+ ions, whereas the other SO3 group of the 2,7-NDS ligand is not coordinated. Eu3+ ions are linked together through bridging the SO3 group, resulting in an infinite chain along the a axis, which is linked by OH groups along the b axis. Thus, the structure of 1D double chain is formed, which resembles a ladder containing Eu-SO3 chains and OH spacers (b). The IP molecule acts as a terminal ligand to chelate the Eu3+ ion by its two N atoms, which is on the side of the chain and inhibits the formation of the high-dimensional framework structure. The distances of Eu···Eu are 3.7796(12) and 7.0630(19) Å by the OH group and SO3 groups, respectively. The adjacent chains are connected by O–H···O/N–H···O hydrogen bonds (O···O distance, 2.7067(6) Å; N···O distance, 2.8752(6) Å) to result in a 3D supramolecular network (Figure S1). It is interesting to note that there are two free Lewis basic N sites on the IP ligand, which shows the potential sensing function for the recognition of metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of the Crystal Structure

The synthetic Ln-MOFs (1-5) crystallize in the triclinic system, P1̅ space group (). Complexes 1-5 are isostructural 1-D double chain structures. A comparison of the crystal data (Table S1) for 1-5 shows that the corresponding Ln-O, Ln-N, and Ln⋅⋅⋅Ln distances decrease in the order of complexes 1-5, which is consistent with the radius Sm3+ > Eu3+ > Gd3+ > Tb3+ > Dy3+. Eu-MOF, 2, is used as an example to discuss the crystal structure. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one Eu3+ ion, one 2,7-NDS ligand, one IP ligand, one OH group, and two water molecules (a). The eight-coordinate Eu3+ ion is completed by two O atoms of 2,7-NDS ligands, two N atoms of chelating IP ligand, two OH groups, and two water molecules, forming a [EuO6N2] distorted square antiprism unit. The bond distances of Eu-O (SO3 group), Eu-O (water), and Eu-N are in the range from 2.474(4) to 2.452(4) Å, 2.274(4) to 2.492(4) Å and 2.563(4) to 2.628(4) Å with an average of 2.463, 2.377, and 2.596 Å, respectively. The one SO3 group of the 2,7-NDS ligand adopts a μ2:η1η1η0 bridging coordination mode and is bonded to two Eu3+ ions, whereas the other SO3 group of the 2,7-NDS ligand is not coordinated. Eu3+ ions are linked together through bridging the SO3 group, resulting in an infinite chain along the a axis, which is linked by OH groups along the b axis. Thus, the structure of 1D double chain is formed, which resembles a ladder containing Eu-SO3 chains and OH spacers (b). The IP molecule acts as a terminal ligand to chelate the Eu3+ ion by its two N atoms, which is on the side of the chain and inhibits the formation of the high-dimensional framework structure. The distances of Eu⋅⋅⋅Eu are 3.7796(12) and 7.0630(19) Å by the OH group and SO3 groups, respectively. The adjacent chains are connected by O-H⋅⋅⋅O/N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (O⋅⋅⋅O distance, 2.7067(6) Å; N⋅⋅⋅O distance, 2.8752(6) Å) to result in a 3D supramolecular network (Figure S1). It is interesting to note that there are two free Lewis basic N sites on the IP ligand, which shows the potential sensing function for the recognition of metal ions.

elements.content: The phase purity of the as-synthesized complexes 1–5 was further confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figure S2). Complexes 1–5 are stable in the air, and the thermal stability was obtained by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) in the temperature range 25–800 °C (Figure S3). Taking 2 as an example, the TGA data indicate that the Eu-MOF releases the water molecules between 89 and 220 °C, corresponding to a weight loss of approximately 6.01%, consistent with the theoretical value of 6.25%, and this loss results in the dehydrated compound, which is thermally stable to 400 °C. On further heating, the ligand molecules are released. Solvent stability of 2 is investigated by PXRD. Complex 2 is dispersed in some solvents for 2 days, including acetone, ethyl acetate, ethanol, acetonitrile and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The solid samples are then collected, and PXRD measurements are carried out. Their PXRD patterns are the same as complex 2 crystal data (Figure S4a), indicating that complex 2 has good solvent stability. Besides, complex 2 is immersed in pH = 3 and 13 aqueous solutions for 2 days, and the result of PXRD shows that the experiment patterns are not changed, comparing the crystal data patterns (Figure S4b), which is showing the framework of 2 can retain good stability in pH = 3 and 13 solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Chemical Stabilities

The phase purity of the as-synthesized complexes 1-5 was further confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figure S2). Complexes 1-5 are stable in the air, and the thermal stability was obtained by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) in the temperature range 25-800 °C (Figure S3). Taking 2 as an example, the TGA data indicate that the Eu-MOF releases the water molecules between 89 and 220 °C, corresponding to a weight loss of approximately 6.01%, consistent with the theoretical value of 6.25%, and this loss results in the dehydrated compound, which is thermally stable to 400 °C. On further heating, the ligand molecules are released. Solvent stability of 2 is investigated by PXRD. Complex 2 is dispersed in some solvents for 2 days, including acetone, ethyl acetate, ethanol, acetonitrile and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The solid samples are then collected, and PXRD measurements are carried out. Their PXRD patterns are the same as complex 2 crystal data (Figure S4a), indicating that complex 2 has good solvent stability. Besides, complex 2 is immersed in pH = 3 and 13 aqueous solutions for 2 days, and the result of PXRD shows that the experiment patterns are not changed, comparing the crystal data patterns (Figure S4b), which is showing the framework of 2 can retain good stability in pH = 3 and 13 solutions.

elements.content: Photoluminescence of MOFs (1–5). The luminescence spectra of solid-state complexes and the ligands were collected at room temperature. The ligand emissions are attributed to the π*−π transition, with centered bands at 360 nm for 2,7-NDS (λex = 285 nm) and 460 nm for IP (λex = 315 nm). The characteristic emission peaks of Sm3+ and Dy3+ in Sm-MOF and Dy-MOF are not obvious, showing broad emission bands from 400 to 500 nm (Figure S5). The luminescent behaviors of the two complexes indicate ineffective energy transfers from the ligands to Sm3+/Dy3+. For complex 3, the Gd3+ ion has a high excited-state energy of 32 150 cm–1, and ligands cannot transfer energy to Gd3+. Therefore, the Gd-MOF exhibits a ligand-based broad emission band centered at 450 nm. Interestingly, the emission of Gd-MOF is in the blue-green region with CIE (0.264.0.321).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Property

Photoluminescence of MOFs (1-5). The luminescence spectra of solid-state complexes and the ligands were collected at room temperature. The ligand emissions are attributed to the π*-π transition, with centered bands at 360 nm for 2,7-NDS (λex = 285 nm) and 460 nm for IP (λex = 315 nm). The characteristic emission peaks of Sm3+ and Dy3+ in Sm-MOF and Dy-MOF are not obvious, showing broad emission bands from 400 to 500 nm (Figure S5). The luminescent behaviors of the two complexes indicate ineffective energy transfers from the ligands to Sm3+/Dy3+. For complex 3, the Gd3+ ion has a high excited-state energy of 32150 cm-1, and ligands cannot transfer energy to Gd3+. Therefore, the Gd-MOF exhibits a ligand-based broad emission band centered at 450 nm. Interestingly, the emission of Gd-MOF is in the blue-green region with CIE (0.264.0.321).

elements.content: The excitation spectrum of Eu-MOF (2) was monitored at 613 nm, corresponding to the 5D0 → 7F2 transition of the Eu3+ ion (). The excitation spectrum shows a large broad band at 250–400 nm, with a maximum of 368 nm due to the π–π* transition from the ligands. The absorption band resides at long wavelengths, more than 350 nm and at longer ranges of up to 400 nm, falling within the visible-light region (a). Especially, the full-width- at-half-maximum of the absorption band is in the range 285–400 nm, implying that the luminescence of Eu3+ ion can be sensitized upon the near-visible light excitation. The emission spectrum of 2 was determined at the excitation maxima of 368 nm, and the characteristic emission peaks with different intensities are observed at 579, 595, 613, 650, and 700 nm, corresponding to the transitions 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0–4) of Eu3+ (a). The strongest emission is at 613 nm from the 5D0 → 7F2 transition, resulting in red luminescence with CIE coordinates (0.544, 0.367). The I[(5D0 → 7F2)/(5D0 → 7F1)] intensity ratio is 3.5, suggesting that the Eu3+ ion is not in an inversion center. This is consistent with the crystal structure. The luminescence quantum yield is 23.13%. The luminescence lifetime of Eu3+ (5D0) is 0.199 ms from its luminescent decay profile by fitting the data with a monoexponential decay curve (Figure S6), indicating that the Eu3+ ion has the same coordination environment. The emission spectra of 2 are also obtained by fixing 300, 310, 320, 330, 340, 350, 360, 380, 385, 390, 395, 400, and 405 nm, respectively, as the excitation wavelengths (Figure S7 and b). Characteristic emission of Eu3+ is also evident. By the excitation wavelengths from 300 to 368 nm or 405 to 368 nm, the relative emission intensity increases gradually. The emission intensity ratio of 5D0 → 7F2 at 613 nm is 0.59:0.62:0.66:0.71:0.73:0.79:1 or 0.20:0.35:0.55:0.74:0.86:0.93:1, respectively. The best excitation wavelength is 368 nm for the Eu-MOF compound. Stupendously, under longer wavelength excitation of 385 nm, a high emission intensity of the Eu3+ ion can also be obtained; even characteristic emission of the Eu3+ ion is also evident upon 390 nm excitation. The emission intensity upon 390 nm excitation is low, only 26% than that upon 368 nm excitation. Indeed, even though at 400 nm excitation, the complex also exhibits characteristic emission of the Eu3+ ion. These excitation wavelengths fall in the near-visible light region, which further confirms that the ligands also can sensitize the Eu3+ ion because of the good absorption of the ligands. The results clearly highlight that the ligands absorb efficiently in the UV–visible spectral range and transfer the energy to the central Eu3+ ion, leading the emission of Eu3+. Therefore, the complex is a potential molecular luminescent material for practical applications involving excitation by long wavelength light.

elements.content: The excitation spectrum of 4 was monitored at 544 nm of the Tb3+15D4 → 7F5 transition, which shows a broad band with a maximum region from 340 to 395 nm () from the π–π* transition of the ligands. Under the maximum excitation of 380 nm, complex 4 displays emissions at 490, 544, 586, and 622 nm, which result from the 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6–3) transitions of Tb3+ (). The most intense emission at 544 nm corresponds to the 5D4 → 7F5 transition. The CIE coordinates are (0.263, 0.463), which is in the green light region. The luminescence quantum yield is 1.56%. The excited-state 5D4 Tb3+ lifetime value was measured by monitoring within the more intense line of 5D4 → 7F5 transition. The observed luminescent decay profile corresponds to an exponential function (Figure S6) with the Tb3+ luminescent lifetime of 0.288 ms. The emission spectra of 4 are also obtained by fixing 320, 330, 340, 350, 360, 370, 380, 385, 390, 395, 400, and 405 nm, respectively, as the excitation wavelengths (Figure S8). Characteristic emission peaks of the 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6–3) transitions of Tb3+ are also evident. The emission intensity ratio of 5D4 → 7F5 at 544 nm is 0.57:0.7:0.76:0.85:0.93:0.99:1:0.92:0.77:0.57:0.36:0.2 upon excitation of 320, 330, 340, 350, 360, 370, 380, 385, 390, 395, 400, and 405 nm, respectively. So, luminescence of complex 4 by long excitation wavelengths is also possible.

elements.content: As it is known, a red, green, and blue tricolor combination can produce white light emission. From the discussion above, Gd-MOF emits a blue-green light, while Eu-MOF shows an intense red light. The luminescence of the Eu-MOF/Gd-MOF motivates us to dope a small amount of Eu3+ into the Gd-MOF to obtain white light emission. Because these Ln-MOFs are isostructural, the two-component Gd0.99803Eu0.00197 – MOF material was synthesized, and its purity was confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figure S9). The Gd/Eu ratios in Gd0.99803Eu0.00197–MOF were determined by ICP analysis. As expected, the emission spectrum of Gd0.99803Eu0.00197 material shows a ligand emission band from 400 to 550 nm and Eu3+ characteristic emission peaks at 579, 595, 613, 650, and 700 nm (Figure S10). As the excitation wavelength is increased from 300 to 395 nm, the CIE coordinates change from (0.275, 0.301) to (0.274, 0.331) (Figure S11 and Table S2). The CIE chromaticity coordinates are (0.323, 0.334) (CRI 87.8, CCT 5960 K) (Figure S10 inset), at an excitation wavelength of 373 nm, which is close to international pure white light CIE chromaticity coordinates (0.333, 0.333), according to the 1931 CIE coordinate diagram. Thus, the Gd0.99803Eu0.00197 material is considered as a white light emission source. However, white light emission based on two-component doped Ln-MOFs is rare in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
White-Light Emission

As it is known, a red, green, and blue tricolor combination can produce white light emission. From the discussion above, Gd-MOF emits a blue-green light, while Eu-MOF shows an intense red light. The luminescence of the Eu-MOF/Gd-MOF motivates us to dope a small amount of Eu3+ into the Gd-MOF to obtain white light emission. Because these Ln-MOFs are isostructural, the two-component Gd0.99803Eu0.00197 - MOF material was synthesized, and its purity was confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figure S9). The Gd/Eu ratios in Gd0.99803Eu0.00197-MOF were determined by ICP analysis. As expected, the emission spectrum of Gd0.99803Eu0.00197 material shows a ligand emission band from 400 to 550 nm and Eu3+ characteristic emission peaks at 579, 595, 613, 650, and 700 nm (Figure S10). As the excitation wavelength is increased from 300 to 395 nm, the CIE coordinates change from (0.275, 0.301) to (0.274, 0.331) (Figure S11 and Table S2). The CIE chromaticity coordinates are (0.323, 0.334) (CRI 87.8, CCT 5960 K) (Figure S10 inset), at an excitation wavelength of 373 nm, which is close to international pure white light CIE chromaticity coordinates (0.333, 0.333), according to the 1931 CIE coordinate diagram. Thus, the Gd0.99803Eu0.00197 material is considered as a white light emission source. However, white light emission based on two-component doped Ln-MOFs is rare in the literature.

elements.content: For Eu3+, the 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0–4) transitions are the most readily observable, which is useful for structural determinations and luminescence sensing. In addition, for Eu3+, the red light emission is easily observed by the naked eye. Interestingly, the absorption window of the Eu-MOF shows a broad band with a maximum absorption range from 350 to 385 nm toward the visible region. Thus, the luminescence sensing properties of 2 were studied under a maximum excitation wavelength of 368 nm. First, the luminescence behavior of the Eu-MOF in various solvents was measured (Figure S12), and it was found that the Eu-MOF shows solvent-dependent emission. The complex exhibits strong emission from the Eu3+ center in common solvents including water, except benzaldehyde, which suggests the possibility of complex 2 being used for luminescence applications in some solvents. So, the luminescence sensing performances of the Eu-MOF are studied in an aqueous system.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing

For Eu3+, the 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0-4) transitions are the most readily observable, which is useful for structural determinations and luminescence sensing. In addition, for Eu3+, the red light emission is easily observed by the naked eye. Interestingly, the absorption window of the Eu-MOF shows a broad band with a maximum absorption range from 350 to 385 nm toward the visible region. Thus, the luminescence sensing properties of 2 were studied under a maximum excitation wavelength of 368 nm. First, the luminescence behavior of the Eu-MOF in various solvents was measured (Figure S12), and it was found that the Eu-MOF shows solvent-dependent emission. The complex exhibits strong emission from the Eu3+ center in common solvents including water, except benzaldehyde, which suggests the possibility of complex 2 being used for luminescence applications in some solvents. So, the luminescence sensing performances of the Eu-MOF are studied in an aqueous system.

elements.content: 2@M (complex 2 (2 mg) aqueous solutions (3 mL) including M­(NO3) n (M = Fe2+, Ca2+, K+, Cr3+, Ba2+, Al3+, Mg2+, Ni2+, Na+, Li+, Co2+, Cd2+, Cu2+, Ag+ and Fe3+, 10–2 mol/L) were prepared, and their luminescence behavior was discussed at the 368 nm excitation. From and Figure S13, it is clear that the characteristic 5D0 → 7F0–4 transitions of Eu3+ were quenched by the cations, and the quenching effects are different. Especially, the luminescence of the Eu3+ ion can be entirely quenched by Ag+ and Fe3+, which shows that the complex can sense Fe3+ or Ag+ ions by luminescence quenching. Furthermore, the concentration detection limit of fluorescence sensing of 2 toward Fe3+ was studied via quantitative fluorescence titration experiments. Two milligrams of sample 2 was immersed in 3 mL of aqueous solution, and Fe3+ was added (0.1 mM, 30 μL added each time). As shown in a, when the Fe3+ concentrations are gradually increased, the relation of the quenching effect (I 0/I – 1) and Fe3+ concentration shows a good linear relation (R 2 = 0.99798), which is explained using the Stern–Volmer equation, I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M] (K sv, quenching constant (M–1); [M], analytes concentration; I 0 and I are emission intensities before and after adding the analytes). The K sv value and the detection limit of 2 toward Fe3+ are calculated to be 1.19 × 105 M–1 and 0.277 μM, respectively (). The detection limit of the Fe3+ is highly desirable, compared with those reported in Table S3. The fluorescence titration experiment of Ag+-incorporated 2 was also performed, and the method is the same as Fe3+ detection. The detection limit for Ag+ is 0.272 μM (). The detection limit meets the 50 μg·L–1 (about 0.46 uM) standard of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for a maximum allowable level of Ag+ in drinking water.

The fluorescence sensing of 2 for antibiotics was measured. Antibiotics are relevant to human life and health, being considered as a necessary drug for treating bacterial infections. Therefore, detecting antibiotics in aqueous solutions is important. The Eu-MOF was evaluated as a fluorescence sensor for detecting antibiotics, such as sulfamethoxazole (SMX), amoxicillin (ACL), azithromycin (AZM), sulfathiazole (STZ), penicillin (PCL), roxithromycin (ROX), ronidazole (RDZ), and ornidazole (ODZ). The luminescence of complex 2 (2 mg) dispersed in antibiotics aqueous solution (0.01 mol/L, 3 mL) was measured under the 368 nm excitation ( and Figure S14). Antibiotics show luminescence quenching for Eu-MOF, in following the order of ODZ > RDZ > ROX > PCL > STZ > AZM, which is calculated for their luminescence quenching efficiencies to be 99.62, 99.24, 23.37, 17.99, 16.01, 8.96%, respectively. It is shown that ODZ and RDZ show the highest quenching efficiencies for luminescence of 2. As a result, the high quenching of ODZ and RDZ for luminescence of 2 might be that the electron-withdrawing group nitro of ODZ and RDZ prevents complex 2 absorption from the excitation energy, and upon excitation, the electron of 2 may transfer to lowest energy orbit of these antibiotics, resulting in fluorescence quenching. Furthermore, similar titration experiments were performed for detecting ODZ and RDZ. The relationship between the luminescence intensity of complex 2 and the concentration of antibiotics was established (b). The relationship is a linear SV plot for ODZ (R 2 = 0.99395) and RDZ (R 2 = 0.99607). The detection limits of 2 toward ODZ and RDZ are 0.319 and 0.51 μM, respectively (). In addition, the addition of interference metal ions or antibiotics does not have an effect on fluorescence sensing for Fe3+, Ag+, or ODZ/RDZ (Figure S15).

elements.content: Most strikingly, the Eu-MOF has a broad absorption band from 250 to 410 nm and still shows strong luminescence even under longer excitation wavelengths from 350 to 385 nm toward the visible region. Considering that complex 2 still emits strong luminescence under the excitation of 385 nm, the fluorescence sensing of 2 for Fe3+, Ag+, and ODZ/RDZ detection in an aqueous medium was investigated under a longer excitation wavelength of 385 nm, and the results are shown in Figure S16 and . As expected, fluorescence sensing of 2 for detection Fe3+, Ag+, and ODZ/RDZ in aqueous medium was also realized. The detection limits of the Eu-MOF toward Fe3+, Ag+, and ODZ/RDZ are calculated to be 0.611, 0.422, and 0.183/0.141 μM, respectively, and these results are compared with those obtained under a maximum excitation wavelength of 368 nm, which is a very significant result.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing under Longer Excitation Wavelength of 385 nm

Most strikingly, the Eu-MOF has a broad absorption band from 250 to 410 nm and still shows strong luminescence even under longer excitation wavelengths from 350 to 385 nm toward the visible region. Considering that complex 2 still emits strong luminescence under the excitation of 385 nm, the fluorescence sensing of 2 for Fe3+, Ag+, and ODZ/RDZ detection in an aqueous medium was investigated under a longer excitation wavelength of 385 nm, and the results are shown in Figure S16 and . As expected, fluorescence sensing of 2 for detection Fe3+, Ag+, and ODZ/RDZ in aqueous medium was also realized. The detection limits of the Eu-MOF toward Fe3+, Ag+, and ODZ/RDZ are calculated to be 0.611, 0.422, and 0.183/0.141 μM, respectively, and these results are compared with those obtained under a maximum excitation wavelength of 368 nm, which is a very significant result.

elements.content: The above experimental results indicate the Eu-MOF shows a high sensitivity and selectivity toward Fe3+, Ag+, and ODZ/RDZ detection in aqueous medium via fluorescence quenching, and the red color luminescence of 2 disappeared under 365 nm light. Thus, the Eu-MOF can sensitively detect these analytes through a distinct color variation, although some luminescence Ln-MOFs have shown good sensing properties for the detection of ions and small molecules. However, the detection limits are comparable to that of other reported MOFs for Fe3+ and ODZ/RDZ detection (Table S3). The highlight is that fluorescence sensing of the Eu-MOF can be achieved under a long excitation wavelength of 385 nm, which is longer than that of our recently developed Eu-MOF. Such significantly fluorescence sensing at a long excitation wavelength is really remarkable. The excitation wavelength at 350 nm < λex < 420 nm belongs to near-visible irradiation, and its energy is appropriate for applications. Specially, visible light is less harmful to biological tissue. These experimental results show that Eu-MOF luminescence sensing can be performed at a broad absorption wavelength between 250 and 410 nm with a maximum range from 350 and 385 nm toward the visible region. Such a feature makes the Eu-complex a highly promising candidate as a sensor in aqueous medium.

elements.content: The PXRD patterns of the Eu-MOF in Fe3+, Ag+, and ODZ/RDZ aqueous solution are in good agreement with the pattern of its crystal structure (Figure S17), indicating that Fe3+, Ag+, and ODZ/RDZ do not affect the structure of the Eu-MOF, and the framework is stable in these aqueous solutions. It is well-known that the Ln3+ luminescence is produced by the energy transfer from the ligand to the Ln3+ ion. The analyte may be absorbed on the surface of the Eu-MOF framework, and the energy transfer is ineffective from ligand to the Eu3+ ion, resulting in luminescence quenching of the complex. As shown in Figure S18, Fe3+ has a strong UV–vis absorption in the range of 250–500 nm, which is completely covering the absorption band of Eu-MOF. The Fe3+ ion may prevent the absorption of the Eu-MOF, and then luminescence of the complex is quenched. In addition, there may be weak interaction between Fe3+ ion and the complex. For luminescence quenching mechanism of the Ag+ ion toward the Eu-MOF, Ag+ has less UV–vis absorption, which is not the reason for the luminescence quenching. Therefore, a possible reason for the luminescence quenching may be the weak interaction between Eu-MOF and Ag+. Ag+ ion has a high interaction affinity to the N atom due to the soft Lewis acidic Ag+ ion and Lewis basic N atom. The fluorescence quenching mechanism of Ag+ toward the Eu-MOF can possibly be attributed to the weak interactions of the Ag+ ion to the N site on the IP ligand in the Eu-MOF, and it may reduce the antenna efficiency of the ligands to the Eu3+ ion, leading to luminescence quenching. The fluorescence quenching mechanism of antibiotics for the Eu-MOF was explained by the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of these antibiotics ( and ). Compared with other antibiotics, the LUMO energy of ODZ and RDZ are lower, and the electrons can easily transfer from the Eu-MOF to them, which causes luminescence quenching of the Eu-MOF. In addition, the UV–visible absorption spectra show that the ODZ and RDZ have strong overlapping with the excitation spectrum of 2, compared other antibiotics (Figure S19). This indicates that ODZ and RDZ can strongly absorb the excitation light, resulting in the luminescence quenching of the Eu-MOF.

It is well-known that the Ln3+ luminescence is produced by the energy transfer from the ligand to the Ln3+ ion. The Fe3+ ion may prevent the absorption of the Eu-MOF, and then luminescence of the complex is quenched. In addition, there may be weak interaction between Fe3+ ion and the complex. For luminescence quenching mechanism of the Ag+ ion toward the Eu-MOF, Ag+ has less UV-vis absorption, which is not the reason for the luminescence quenching. Therefore, a possible reason for the luminescence quenching may be the weak interaction between Eu-MOF and Ag+. Ag+ ion has a high interaction affinity to the N atom due to the soft Lewis acidic Ag+ ion and Lewis basic N atom. The Dy3+ ion shows strong magnetic anisotropy from its large spin–orbit coupling and a crystal field effect, which makes Dy3+ a suitable candidate for the construction of magnetic systems featuring slow magnetic relaxation. The temperature-dependent direct-current (dc) magnetic measurements were performed on Dy-MOF (5) in the range from 2 to 300 K at 1 kOe (). The room temperature value of the χM T is 29.00 cm3 mol–1 K, which is close to the theoretical calculated value of 28.34 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions (a ground-state 6H15/2, S = 5/2, L = 5, J = 15/2, and g = 4/3). With the temperature decrease, the χM T value gradually decreases in a wide temperature range and then reaches a minimum value of 16.44 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The typical behavior is attributable to the thermal depopulation of the excited Stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ion. The field dependence of the magnetization is shown in (inset) at 2, 3, 5, and 8 K, magnetic field ranging from 0 to 50 kOe. The curves of M–H/T show that the magnetization increases fast at low magnetic fields, and the maximum magnetization value reaches 10.83 Nβ at 2 K and 50 kOe, which is lower than the theoretical calculated value 20 Nβ for two Dy3+ ions. The plots M–H/T also show that the temperature dependence magnetizations are no superimposition under different fields. The results indicate the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy in this system.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies of the Dy-MOF

The Dy3+ ion shows strong magnetic anisotropy from its large spin-orbit coupling and a crystal field effect, which makes Dy3+ a suitable candidate for the construction of magnetic systems featuring slow magnetic relaxation. The temperature-dependent direct-current (dc) magnetic measurements were performed on Dy-MOF (5) in the range from 2 to 300 K at 1 kOe (). The room temperature value of the χM T is 29.00 cm3 mol-1 K, which is close to the theoretical calculated value of 28.34 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions (a ground-state 6H15/2, S = 5/2, L = 5, J = 15/2, and g = 4/3). With the temperature decrease, the χM T value gradually decreases in a wide temperature range and then reaches a minimum value of 16.44 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The typical behavior is attributable to the thermal depopulation of the excited Stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ion. The field dependence of the magnetization is shown in  (inset) at 2, 3, 5, and 8 K, magnetic field ranging from 0 to 50 kOe. The curves of M-H/T show that the magnetization increases fast at low magnetic fields, and the maximum magnetization value reaches 10.83 Nβ at 2 K and 50 kOe, which is lower than the theoretical calculated value 20 Nβ for two Dy3+ ions. The plots M-H/T also show that the temperature dependence magnetizations are no superimposition under different fields. The results indicate the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy in this system.

elements.content: To investigate the magnetization dynamics of compound 5, alternating current (ac) susceptibility measurements were measured on the crystalline samples from 1 to 999 Hz (a). Under zero dc field, both the in-phase (χM′) and out-of-phase (χM″) signals exhibit obvious a temperature-/frequency-dependent signal below 14 K. This indicates a slow magnetic relaxation behavior of SMMs. As the temperature gradually decreases, the χM′ and χM″ values gradually increase, whereas it does not pass through the maximum value at 2 K, suggesting that it may be quantum tunneling of the magnetization. Then the 2 kOe dc field was applied to suppress the quantum tunneling (b). The χM′ and χM″ signals show maximum values of ac susceptibility between 6 and 12 K. The maxima maximum value shifts with increasing of frequency, whereas low-frequency peaks occur in the lower temperature region. This behavior coincides with the characteristic of a super-paramagnet. To further confirm the signal relaxation process for compound 5, the Cole–Cole curve of χ′M–χ″M is fitted by using a generalized Debye equation in the temperature range from 2 to 10 K (a and Table S4). Using the extended Debye equation, the relaxation time (τ) can be obtained from fitting χM″ versus f curves at different temperatures. Above 8.5 K, the ln­(τ)–T –1 curve follows the Arrhenius law. The anisotropy energy barrier (U eff/k B) obtained from fitting is 82.39 K with a pre-exponential factor of 2.16 × 10–8 s (b and Table S4).

This indicates a slow magnetic relaxation behavior of SMMs. As the temperature gradually decreases, the χM' and χM" values gradually increase, whereas it does not pass through the maximum value at 2 K, suggesting that it may be quantum tunneling of the magnetization. Then the 2 kOe dc field was applied to suppress the quantum tunneling (b). The χM' and χM" signals show maximum values of ac susceptibility between 6 and 12 K. The maxima maximum value shifts with increasing of frequency, whereas low-frequency peaks occur in the lower temperature region. This behavior coincides with the characteristic of a super-paramagnet. To further confirm the signal relaxation process for compound 5, the Cole-Cole curve of χ'M-χ"M is fitted by using a generalized Debye equation in the temperature range from 2 to 10 K (a and Table S4). Using the extended Debye equation, the relaxation time (τ) can be obtained from fitting χM" versus f curves at different temperatures. Above 8.5 K, the ln(τ)-T -1 curve follows the Arrhenius law. The anisotropy energy barrier (U eff/k B) obtained from fitting is 82.39 K with a pre-exponential factor of 2.16 × 10-8 s (b and Table S4).

elements.content: In this work, the Ln-based MOFs [Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, and Dy ] with 2,7-NDS and IP were constructed. The stability, luminescence, and magnetic properties of the synthetic complexes were studied. A remarkable feature is that the broad absorb chromophore could efficiently sensitize Eu3+ luminescence, which provides a new way for an intense red luminescence with a long wavelength excitation extending well into the near-visible region. This luminescent Eu-MOF is used as a sensor for the detection of Fe3+/Ag+ and ODZ/RDZ in aqueous medium excited with near-visible irradiation, and even under the excitation of a long wavelength of 385 nm, this complex still shows good luminescence sensing ability, which has advantages over the luminescent Eu-MOFs sensors reported in the literature. In addition, an intriguing white light emission based on the two-component Gd0.99803Eu0.00197-MOF is realized. Magnetic studies indicate the Dy-MOF shows SMM behavior, exhibiting slow magnetic relaxation. The design of the Ln-MOFs results in very rich luminescence and magnetic properties for these compounds. This approach may allow for a targeted design of MOFs for applications in luminescence and magnetism.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, the Ln-based MOFs [Ln = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, and Dy ] with 2,7-NDS and IP were constructed. The stability, luminescence, and magnetic properties of the synthetic complexes were studied. A remarkable feature is that the broad absorb chromophore could efficiently sensitize Eu3+ luminescence, which provides a new way for an intense red luminescence with a long wavelength excitation extending well into the near-visible region. This luminescent Eu-MOF is used as a sensor for the detection of Fe3+/Ag+ and ODZ/RDZ in aqueous medium excited with near-visible irradiation, and even under the excitation of a long wavelength of 385 nm, this complex still shows good luminescence sensing ability, which has advantages over the luminescent Eu-MOFs sensors reported in the literature. In addition, an intriguing white light emission based on the two-component Gd0.99803Eu0.00197-MOF is realized. Magnetic studies indicate the Dy-MOF shows SMM behavior, exhibiting slow magnetic relaxation. The design of the Ln-MOFs results in very rich luminescence and magnetic properties for these compounds. This approach may allow for a targeted design of MOFs for applications in luminescence and magnetism.

cln_elements.content: The Dy3+ ion shows strong magnetic anisotropy from its large spin–orbit coupling and a crystal field effect, which makes Dy3+ a suitable candidate for the construction of magnetic systems featuring slow magnetic relaxation. The temperature-dependent direct-current (dc) magnetic measurements were performed on Dy-MOF (5) in the range from 2 to 300 K at 1 kOe (). The room temperature value of the χM T is 29.00 cm3 mol–1 K, which is close to the theoretical calculated value of 28.34 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions (a ground-state 6H15/2, S = 5/2, L = 5, J = 15/2, and g = 4/3). With the temperature decrease, the χM T value gradually decreases in a wide temperature range and then reaches a minimum value of 16.44 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The typical behavior is attributable to the thermal depopulation of the excited Stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ion. The field dependence of the magnetization is shown in (inset) at 2, 3, 5, and 8 K, magnetic field ranging from 0 to 50 kOe. The curves of M–H/T show that the magnetization increases fast at low magnetic fields, and the maximum magnetization value reaches 10.83 Nβ at 2 K and 50 kOe, which is lower than the theoretical calculated value 20 Nβ for two Dy3+ ions. The plots M–H/T also show that the temperature dependence magnetizations are no superimposition under different fields. The results indicate the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy in this system.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies of the Dy-MOF

The Dy3+ ion shows strong magnetic anisotropy from its large spin-orbit coupling and a crystal field effect, which makes Dy3+ a suitable candidate for the construction of magnetic systems featuring slow magnetic relaxation. The temperature-dependent direct-current (dc) magnetic measurements were performed on Dy-MOF (5) in the range from 2 to 300 K at 1 kOe (). The room temperature value of the χM T is 29.00 cm3 mol-1 K, which is close to the theoretical calculated value of 28.34 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions (a ground-state 6H15/2, S = 5/2, L = 5, J = 15/2, and g = 4/3). With the temperature decrease, the χM T value gradually decreases in a wide temperature range and then reaches a minimum value of 16.44 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The typical behavior is attributable to the thermal depopulation of the excited Stark sublevels of the Dy3+ ion. The field dependence of the magnetization is shown in  (inset) at 2, 3, 5, and 8 K, magnetic field ranging from 0 to 50 kOe. The curves of M-H/T show that the magnetization increases fast at low magnetic fields, and the maximum magnetization value reaches 10.83 Nβ at 2 K and 50 kOe, which is lower than the theoretical calculated value 20 Nβ for two Dy3+ ions. The plots M-H/T also show that the temperature dependence magnetizations are no superimposition under different fields. The results indicate the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy in this system.
